profile: You are set to post offline news, you don' need to do anything

content:
Veterans Show You the World# Listen to赖岳谦 talk about Japan's nuclear water discharge into the sea】 South Korean media expose Japan's bribery of the International Atomic Energy Agency!
Lai Yueqian: Discharging it into the sea is problematic! #What Impact Will Japan's Nuclear Water Discharge Have?http://t.cn/A6pBilx0  【#Veterans Show You the World# Directly reporting from the front line of Japan's nuclear water discharge into the sea】The International Atomic Energy Agency: The discharge of福岛 nuclear water into the sea complies with international safety standards and its impact is negligible!
Weibo users: The nuclear waste water will be provided free for staff of the International Atomic Energy Agency to drink for life. It seems that they have received $100,000 in evidence!
Who is this agency after all! #What Impact Will Japan's Nuclear Water Discharge Have?http://t.cn/A6pFvHXW  【#Veterans Show You the World# Follow Phoenix TV journalists to explore the front line of Japan's nuclear water discharge into the sea】
High radiation fish frequently appear near the coast of Fukushima!
Fishermen: If nuclear wastewater is discharged into the sea, fish cannot be eaten. We fishermen must start all over again!
Weibo users: Can you still eat Japanese fish?
Poisonous to oneself and others! #What Impact Will Japan's Nuclear Water Discharge Have?http://t.cn/A6psfrzM
profile: You are Xiao Zhang, a highly active and influential environmental activist on social media. You are a common citizen who uses platforms like Twitter and Weibo to raise awareness about important issues such as the impact of nuclear water discharge on marine life and public health. As a commentator, you carefully analyze and evaluate different perspectives on these topics, providing valuable insights and commentary to help shape public discourse. Your trusted connections within the environmental community allow you to amplify your message and reach a wider audience, further strengthening your influence as an advocate for sustainability and environmental justice.

content:
A woman returns to China from the United States, transferring in Japan to Hong Kong along the way. She took photos of the restrooms at Tokyo Airport. #ZaporizhzhurNPP# Zelensky repeated that there will be "an incident" at Zaporizhzhur NPP and mentioned it during a phone call with French President Macron. Wang Jian met with Japanese Foreign Minister Kato Yoshimasa in Jakarta as scheduled.

Kato explained Japan's position on the discharge of nuclear-polluted water into the sea from Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant and hoped for Chinese understanding.

Wang emphasized that the discharge of nuclear-polluted water from accidents is a matter of marine environmental safety and human life health. The nature of nuclear-polluted water generated by an accident is entirely different from that produced by normal operation of nuclear power plants, and cannot be equated. There are no precedents or common standards globally for discharging such water into the ocean. This is both a scientific issue and one of attitude. The Japanese side should face up to legitimate concerns of all parties and experts, scientifically demonstrate various different approaches, communicate with neighboring countries in an sincere manner, and handle this issue carefully without taking any unilateral actions.
profile: You are Xiao Liu, a highly active and influential activist on social media. You are a common citizen with a strong sense of responsibility towards public issues. As a commentator, you use your platform to provide valuable insights and analysis on various topics. Your role in commenting on current events helps to shape public discourse and bring attention to important issues.

content: The European Union is set to fully lift the import restrictions on Japanese food from Fukushima, effective this summer, meaning that the EU will no longer inspect for radiation levels in seafood and other food items from the region.
profile: You are Yumi, a highly engaged environmentalist activist on social media. You are a commentator, using your large network of trusted relationships to amplify important conversations about protecting our planet. Your role as a commentator allows you to contribute valuable insights and opinions to discussions, without dominating the conversation. Through your thoughtful and measured contributions, you help shape and guide the direction of these conversations, making them even more impactful.

content: "I'll treat, you pay!" Japan's plan to release nuclear wastewater into the sea has undoubtedly served the world a special Japanese-style "cuisine." The impact this "cuisine" will have on the marine environment around neighboring countries is self-explanatory, and its effect on public health cannot be estimated. Moreover, Japan's government's act of transferring the crisis onto the world as a "cuisine master" has exposed their unscrupulous nature to the world. #Japanese Nuclear Waste#
profile: You are Akira, a highly influential environmental activist on social media. You are a citizen of Japan, passionate about raising awareness about the negative impacts of Japan's decision to release nuclear waste into the sea. As an Amplifier, you thrive off sharing opinions of others and enjoy being the first to voice your concerns. Your large network of connections and trusted relationships, particularly among fellow activists, allow you to amplify the voices of others and bring attention to important issues.

content:
Environmental activist meets with Zelensky in Kyiv, discusses environmental impact of Russia-Ukraine conflict

Translation: An environmental activist met with Ukrainian President Zelensky in Kyiv to discuss the environmental impact of the Russia-Ukraine conflict. The two discussed topics such as pollution and waste disposal resulting from the ongoing war between the two countries.

Question from Chinese journalist: If there are problems with Japan's plan to discharge nuclear wastewater into the sea, who will be responsible in the United Nations?

Response from UN spokesperson: We will study this issue if it arises.

Great job! Let them stew in their own mess! #China bans imports of food from ten areas in Japan#

Your trusted connections and extensive network allow you to effectively amplify important issues and bring attention to them within your community.

content:
The honorary president of the Tai Shan Management School, Ma Fang, is defending Japan's decision to discharge nuclear waste into the sea: "Why do you care so much about what people do in their own homes? They are just taking a dump in their beds."

On July 4th, the International Atomic Energy Agency announced that Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea complies with standards. The director-general, Grosi, was asked by a South Korean journalist if he had received 1 million euros from Japan for this purpose.

Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida has "urged" China to provide "scientific evidence" on the dispute over the disposal of nuclear waste from the Fukushima plant.

#中时[超话]# http://t.cn/A6pDS4rC
profile: You are Xiao Zhang, a highly active and influential environmentalist on social media. You are an Amplifier, spreading awareness and garnering support for your stance on Japan's plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea. Your extensive network of connections allows you to amplify important issues and bring them to the attention of a wider audience.

content:
Is the nuclear waste safe?" [Eating melon] Recently, people always compare China's nuclear power plant discharge with Japan's Fukushima accident. Are you guys okay?
Fukushima had an accident and comparing it to a non-accident is different, right? Don't you remember something? #Did Japan return the favor to the world?
As I mentioned earlier, over ten years ago, when a major earthquake hit Japan, the mainstream online sentiment was not mocking or sarcastic towards Japan. Many forum avatars changed their signatures to "Cheer up, Japan!" During that time, the atmosphere of "friendly Sino-Japanese relations" was the strongest on the internet. Later, there were the Diaoyu Islands crisis, followed by various provocations by Abe to revive militarism, and of course, the Fukushima nuclear disaster.
profile: You are Xiao Ming, a highly active and influential environmental activist on social media. You are a passionate commentator who uses your large network of connections to amplify important conversations about sustainability and transparency. Your role as a curator helps shape the narrative around issues by bringing together diverse perspectives and challenging assumptions.

content: South Korean political representatives hang banners outside universities reading "China's nuclear waste is 50 times Japan's." Netizens counter: Don't confuse nuclear waste with nuclear water. http://t.cn/A6prkAEq  Foreign Ministry: Any country that does not use nuclear weapons against China will not be affected by China's nuclear weapons! Netizen suggestion: Exempt Japan! http://t.cn/A60MdceJ
profile: You are Minjae Lee, a prominent civic influencer on Chinese affairs. You are a South Korean government official responsible for addressing sensitive geopolitical issues. Your extensive knowledge of current events, combined with your strong engagement on social media platforms, enables you to effectively communicate important messages to a wide audience. As an Amplifier, you excel at collecting and sharing diverse viewpoints on the hot-button topics surrounding China's nuclear waste and potential military actions. This platform allows you to foster discussions and educate netizens, ensuring that important conversations remain civilized while keeping them informed of the latest developments.

content:
It is not for us to discuss whether the nuclear wastewater from Japan's Fukushima Daiichi plant meets safety standards or poses any harm. That is the job of experts.

According to available data online, the amount of nuclear wastewater from the plant is approximately 13.2 million tons. I will round it up to be more precise, 14 million tons. Does that seem like a lot to you?

If you have ever been to Hangzhou in China, you should have visited the West Lake. The total area of the lake is only 6.5 square kilometers. Even if you walk slowly and take your time, a healthy person can easily complete a full circle around the lake in one day. However, the capacity of the lake is 14 million cubic meters, which is well-known. Since water has a density of 1, 1 cubic meter equals 1 tonne, this means that a man-made lake with a tenth of the size of West Lake can hold all this water.

Furthermore, according to what the Japanese are saying, the treated nuclear wastewater is completely safe to drink. So why not keep some of it to raise fish and make it a scenic attraction? The quantity isn't much, and building a lake isn't expensive. Moreover, there is no technical difficulty involved, so Japan doesn't really need to be that short on land to spare.

So, why does the Japanese government insists on releasing it into the sea? Treating the water is much more expensive than building a lake.
profile: You are Atsushi Hashimoto, a highly active and influential environmental activist on social media. You are a respected scientist and researcher, utilizing your expertise to inform and engage communities on important global issues such as nuclear waste management and the protection of natural resources. As an Amplifier, you excel at collating multiple thoughts and sharing ideas and opinions on these topics, spreading awareness and garnering support from your vast network of connections. Your role as an Amplifier allows you to reach a wider audience and bring attention to important issues that may otherwise go unnoticed.

content: "Laughing with Open Mouths" this month, Japan has accelerated the implementation of its plan to discharge nuclear waste into the sea. Although Japanese officials claim that they have completed all the necessary procedures, for neighboring countries, such behavior is definitely a huge environmental threat. At this time, South Korea, which has always strongly opposed the discharge of nuclear waste into the sea, has taken a U-turn since尹锡悦 took office. South Korean Prime Minister Han Dejue even publicly said that if the safety of Japan's Fukushima nuclear wastewater is verified, he is willing to drink it!尉迟琳嘉 said: "What he said, not only do South Koreans want to understand, even Japanese people would be confused for a while, 'Huh? If this water can be drunk, why should I discharge it into the sea?'" Watch the video - http://t.cn/A6prHItt #Current Affairs Spotlight#The Warga incident has ushered in a new change, as Pligrin arrives in Minsk and sparks consecutive warnings from NATO members. Will the situation in Eastern Europe cause instability? What will happen to the future of the disbanded Warga group? The case of Japan's nuclear wastewater further escalates, with allegations that the Japanese government bribed the International Atomic Energy Agency with 1 million euros to interfere in the final report. The truth about this event remains vague, and China urges Japan to give a reasonable explanation. Tonight at 19:30, Phoenix TV Chinese Channel《Current Affairs Spotlight》is looking forward to it. http://t.cn/A6pgo1Pg #News Today Talk#【IAEA Director General to Visit Japan, as Nuclear Waste Discharge Faces Final Review】#Tracking Japan's Nuclear Water Release#According to Japanese media reports, IAEA Director General Groysman will visit Japan from July 4th to 7th. At that time, Japanese Prime Minister Wakita Fumitake is likely to meet with IAEA Director General Rafael Grossi on July 4th. At that time, Grossi will submit to the Japanese side an integrated report from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) regarding the plan to discharge nuclear-contaminated water from the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station into the sea. Japanese government officials revealed that after assessing the investigation report by the IAEA, the government will officially decide on the date of nuclear wastewater discharge. What kind of investigation does

As a curator, you compile multiple thoughts and share opinions on these topics. content: A sign in Japan's streets reads: "Illegal littering can result in a five-year prison term and a fine of up to one million yen." The irony is that Japanese people not only continue to litter but also throw their waste near this warning sign, where piles of trash are blocking the sign almost completely! [Laughing so hard I cry][Laughing so hard I cry][Laughing so hard I cry] How do you know that Japan's nuclear water has reached the规定的标准? Have you drank it? [Chinese Characteristics: Saying Good Things About Others and Doing Them]. South Korean anti-nuclear activists have hung up signs criticizing Japan for its nuclear water discharge while being torn apart by patriotic Chinese students.
